Award.AwardTitle: 20th Anniversary Workshop for the NSF/DOE Partnership in Basic Plasma Science and Engineering
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support a two-and-one-half day workshop celebrating the 20th anniversary of the NSF/DOE Partnership in Basic Plasma Science and Engineering. In the 20 years that the Partnership has existed, it has funded over 200 Principal Investigators for research on a wide range of topics including high energy density plasmas, low temperature plasmas, astrophysical and space plasmas, plasma based accelerators, etc. The Partnership has funded the research of many students and postdocs, some of whom have gone on to become Principal Investigators of NSF and DOE awards in their own right. All current and former Principal Investigators, as well as several current and former program officers at NSF and DOE who have had significant roles in creating, organizing, and managing the Partnership were invited to attend. The expected attendance is about 100 researchers as well as representatives of NSF, DOE, and other federal government agencies involved in supporting plasma science and engineering.

The workshop attendees will discuss the scientific achievements supported by the NSF/DOE Partnership in Basic Plasma Science and Engineering over the past 20 years, as well as the future of the field of basic plasma physics and its applications. The workshop will include a session discussing the history of the Partnership, 26 invited scientific talks, a poster session with 28 poster presentations, and two panel discussions. This award is being co-funded by the Division of Physics, the Division of Astronomical Sciences, the Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences, and the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems.

ProgramElement.Text: Proc Sys, Reac Eng & Mol Therm

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award covered expenses for a workshop in held  at NSF in January 2017 organized by Profs. Ellen Zweibel (U. Wisconsin), Jorge Rocca (Colorado State Univ.), and Ed Thomas (Auburn Univ.)  in celebration of the 20th anniversary of the NSF-DOE Partnership in Basic Plasma Science. All current and former Principal Investigators as well as highly ranked officials at the National Science Foundation, the Department of Energy, and other select Federal agencies were invited to attend.

The  program featured oral presentations, poster presentations, and 2 panel discussions. There was a lively level of  interaction throughout, often bridging subfields.  All participants came away with an awareness of the extraordinarily broad range and high quality of science that the Partnership has supported (which spanned plasma based medicine, environmental monitoring, advanced computing, and exotic cosmic radiation sources!), the respect its rigorous review process has garnered both in the research community and at the Agencies, and the impact the Partnership has had on the careers of the PIs and their students.Participants also reflected on the work remianing to be done to increase the visibility of plasma science across STEM fields and to increase the proportion of women and ethnic minorities in the field.

Following the workshop, a group led by Ellen Zweibel produced a report on the Workshop and the Partnership that has been circulated within the funding agencies and is available to everyone on the conference website.

 


Last Modified: 03/30/2018
Modified by: Ellen G Zweibel
